contentrichtext.text: {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2012}} '''Sir Richard Whitbourne''' (1579<ref>referred to as "Captaine Richard Whitbourne of Exmouth" in ''[http://eebo.chadwyck.com/search/full_rec?SOURCE=config.cfg&ACTION=ByID&ID=71305220 At Theobalds, the 12. of Aprill 1622. The copy of a reference from the Kings most excellent Maiesty: as also a letter from the right honourable lords of His Maiesties most honourable Priuy Councell, to the most reuerend fathers in God, the lords arch-bishops of Canterbury and Yorke their graces.]'' (login required)</ref> – 1628) was an English [[colony|colonist]], author and mariner. Richard Whitbourne was born in [[Exmouth]] in Devon, England. Whilst apprenticed to a merchant adventurer of [[Southampton]], he sailed extensively around [[Europe]] and twice to [[Newfoundland (island)|Newfoundland]]. He served in a ship of his own against the [[Great Armada]] under Lord Admiral [[Thomas Howard, 1st Earl of Suffolk]]. He spent the next thirty years in cod fishing off [[Newfoundland (island)|Newfoundland]]. He assisted the pirates [[Peter Easton]] and [[Henry Mainwaring]] to seek pardons from [[James I of England]].<ref>Richard Whidborne (2005) Crosses & Comforts: The Life and Times of Captain Sir Richard Whitbourne, ISBN 0-9549655-0-7</ref> Asked by [[William Vaughan (Welsh writer and colonial investor)|William Vaughan]] to [[Proprietary Governor|govern]] his [[colony]] at [[Renews]] in [[Colony of Newfoundland|Newfoundland]], he did so from 1618 until 1620 when Vaughan abandoned the venture. Whitbourne was sent to establish law and order in the colony, he was the first to hold a court of justice in [[North America]] at [[Trinity, Newfoundland and Labrador|Trinity]] in 1615.<ref>[[Paul O'Neill (author)|Paul O'Neill]] (2003) The Oldest City, The Story of [[St. John's, Newfoundland and Labrador|St. John's]], [[Newfoundland and Labrador|Newfoundland]] (p. 81), ISBN 0-9730271-2-6</ref> In 1620, Whitbourne published ''A Discourse and Discovery of New-found-land'' in order to promote colonisation on the island. ==See also== *[[List of Newfoundland and Labrador
